articles.headline: ‘We’re All Climate Economists Now’
articles.snippet: With climate change affecting everything from household finances to electric grids, the profession is increasingly focused on how society can mitigate carbon emissions and cope with their impact.
articles.abstract: With climate change affecting everything from household finances to electric grids, the profession is increasingly focused on how society can mitigate carbon emissions and cope with their impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early January in San Antonio, dozens of Ph.D. economists packed into a small windowless room in the recesses of a Grand Hyatt to hear brand-new research on the hottest topic of their annual conference: how climate change is affecting everything.

articles.headline: Trump’s Win Adds to Air of Inevitability as Haley Sharpens Edge
articles.snippet: The former president’s victories in Iowa last week and in New Hampshire on Tuesday leave his main Republican rival, Nikki Haley, with an uphill battle.
articles.abstract: The former president’s victories in Iowa last week and in New Hampshire on Tuesday leave his main Republican rival, Nikki Haley, with an uphill battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s victory in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday provided him the second of an opening pair of wins in the Republican nomination fight that accelerated his push for the party to coalesce behind him and deepened questions about the path forward for Nikki Haley, his lone remaining rival.

articles.headline: How a Ragtag Militia in Yemen Became a Nimble U.S. Foe
articles.snippet: The Iran-backed Houthis perfected the tactics of irregular warfare during years of conflict against a Saudi-led coalition, military officials say.
articles.abstract: The Iran-backed Houthis perfected the tactics of irregular warfare during years of conflict against a Saudi-led coalition, military officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, the scrappy Iran-backed Yemeni rebels known as the Houthis did such a good job of bedeviling American partners in the Middle East that Pentagon war planners started copying some of their tactics.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: An Olympic Dream Falters Amid Track’s Shifting Rules
articles.snippet: Track and field’s decision to bar intersex athletes from women’s events has raised questions about fair play and inclusion ahead of the Paris Games.
articles.abstract: Track and field’s decision to bar intersex athletes from women’s events has raised questions about fair play and inclusion ahead of the Paris Games.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maximila Imali, a top Kenyan sprinter, did not lose her eligibility to compete in the Paris Olympics because she cheated. She did not fail a doping test. She broke no rules.

articles.headline: The Sports Illustrated Cover, a Faded Canvas That Once Defined Sports
articles.snippet: It used to be the most coveted real estate in sports journalism. But its power to set the agenda disappeared along with its elite photographers.
articles.abstract: It used to be the most coveted real estate in sports journalism. But its power to set the agenda disappeared along with its elite photographers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe it was the wordless image of the United States Olympic hockey team celebrating the “Miracle on Ice.” Perhaps it was the perfect frame of Dwight Clark making “The Catch” to send the San Francisco 49ers to the 1982 Super Bowl. Or it could have been the declaration that a 17-year-old LeBron James was “The Chosen One,” 20 months before he played in his first N.B.A. game.
articles.byline: By Kevin Draper and Benjamin Mullin

articles.headline: British Court Answers an Eternal Question: How Much Potato Does a Crisp Contain?
articles.snippet: A snack company’s yearslong effort to protect the sanctity of its poppadom spuddered — er, sputtered — in a tax tribunal this month.
articles.abstract: A snack company’s yearslong effort to protect the sanctity of its poppadom spuddered — er, sputtered — in a tax tribunal this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: No profit grows, Shakespeare once wrote, where no pleasure is taken. And so in the tedious march of life, we find joy in small things: The rising of the sun. A fine glass of wine. The greasy snap of a well-dressed potato crisp.

articles.headline: Military Plane Crashes in Russia, Killing All Aboard, Moscow Says
articles.snippet: The Russian Defense Ministry claimed that the transport plane was carrying 65 Ukrainian prisoners of war and accused Ukraine of shooting it down. The claims could not be independently verified.
articles.abstract: The Russian Defense Ministry claimed that the transport plane was carrying 65 Ukrainian prisoners of war and accused Ukraine of shooting it down. The claims could not be independently verified.
articles.lead_paragraph: A large Russian military transport plane crashed on Wednesday near the border with Ukraine, killing everyone onboard, the Russian Defense Ministry said, accusing Ukraine of shooting down the plane with missiles.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: Why Making Face Computers Cool Isn’t Easy
articles.snippet: Starting with Google Glass, all have been plagued with the same issues, even as Apple plunges into the market with its Vision Pro.
articles.abstract: Starting with Google Glass, all have been plagued with the same issues, even as Apple plunges into the market with its Vision Pro.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of anticipation, Apple’s first major new product in nearly a decade has arrived. The $3,500 Vision Pro, a face computer that resembles ski goggles, will be released next week.
